questions.question: True or false: If you end up missing one of the online lecture quizzes for a good reason, such as being sick, you should immediately contact the professor about your situation and request an extension on the quiz.

answers.comment: Extensions are not granted for the online lecture quizzes for any reason. Instead, the lowest three quiz scores will be dropped automatically for each student so that you won't have to take a zero on a quiz if you miss one or two due to being sick, having your internet go out at the last moment, etc. So, please do not contact your professor and ask for an extension if you miss an online lecture quiz. questions.question: Studies have shown which of the following to be a particularly effective way for most students to learn new material?

answers.text: repeatedly going over their notes about the material
repeatedly going back over textbook readings about the material
repeatedly answering questions about the material

questions.correct_answer: repeatedly answering questions about the material
questions.neutral_comments: In one study, different groups of students were shown a list of vocabulary words. The students were then divided into three groups. The first group of students kept studying (reading over) the list of vocabulary words. The second group alternated between reading over the list of words and being tested on them. The third group kept being tested on the list of words. The first group of students did the worst on tests of the vocabulary words. Interestingly, the second and third groups of students did about equally well. This study suggests that repeatedly going over and over study questions is generally a more effective method of learning new material than repeatedly going over the reading (either from the textbook or from your notes). (And, going over your notes is likely to be more effective than going over the textbook).

questions.neutral_comments: The lab is a critical part of BIOL 1009. The only way to get the lab experience is to be present in lab. For that reason, to pass the course students may miss no more than three lab sessions for ANY reason.

questions.question: Scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on exams or plagiarism, is not tolerated in this course. BIOL 1009 is a required course for almost all students taking it. This means that the information covered in the course is information students will likely need to be successful in their future careers. As a result, committing scholastic dishonesty in this course is not only dis-honorable, but is also likely to negatively impact students' future careers. Because scholastic dishonesty is not tolerated in this course, students found to have committed scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on an exam:

answers.text: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
will be given a second chance if they promise not to do it again.
will be given an opportunity to make up some or all of the points they lost by getting a "0" on an exam or other assignment.

questions.correct_answer: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
questions.neutral_comments: Integrity is taken seriously in this course. The minimum penalty for students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be a grade of "0" on the assignment or exam in question, with no second chances or opportunities to make up any of the lost points. In addition, 100% of students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be reported to the UMN Office of Community Standards.

questions.question: When a reversible chemical reaction reaches equilibrium,

answers.text: the forward and reverse reactions stop
the relative concentrations of reactants and products continues to change
the concentrations of reactants and products are equal
the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate

questions.correct_answer: the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate
questions.neutral_comments: At equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate. This does not mean that the concentrations of reactants and products are equal. Typically one will be significantly higher than the other. But, the relative concentrations of the reactants and products will cease to change. For example, if A and B are converted to C and D, and C and D are converted to A and B in the reverse reaction, then equilibrium is reached when the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is the same as the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. If the reaction of A and B to form C and D is more energetically favorable than the reaction of C and D to form A and B, equilibrium may not be reached until the concentrations of C and D are significantly higher than the concentrations of A and B. At that point, even though individual molecules of A and B may be more likely to react to form molecules of C and D, because there are so many more molecules of C and D the rate at which molecules of C and D are converted to A and B becomes the same as the rate at which molecules of A and B are converted to C and D. For example, imagine a test tube in which there are 1,000 molecules each of A and B and that 10% of them interact per minute to form C and D. That would mean that the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is 100 per minute. If the there are 10,000 molecules each of C and D in the test tube and 1% of them react per minute to form A and B, the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B would also be 100 per minute, indicating that the system is at equilibrium. If you removed some of the molecules of C and D from the test tube, right after you removed the C and D the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be unchanged, but the rate of conversion of C and D would decrease. So, the system would no longer be at equilibrium as the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be higher than the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. Because of this, the relative concentrations of A and B versus C and D would also be changing, with C and D increasing relative to A and B. Eventually, the concentrations of C and D would increase enough and the concentrations of A and B would decrease enough so that the rates of the forward and reverse reactions would become equal, meaning that equilibrium would be re-established.

Pure water at room temperature has a concentration of 10-7 hydrogen ions (H+) and 10-7 hydroxyl ions (OH-). Why is this?

answers.text: Because at any given moment 1 in 1014 water molecules is broken apart into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions.
Because water will absorb oxygen molecules from the atmosphere and some of those oxygen molecules will combine with hydrogen atoms from the water.
Because at any given moment 1 in 103.5 water molecules is broken apart into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions.
Because at any given moment 1 in 107 water molecules is broken apart into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions.

questions.correct_answer: Because at any given moment 1 in 107 water molecules is broken apart into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions.

questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydrogen ion [H+] concentration of 10-8 M?
questions.correct_answer: pH 8
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. The base 10 logarithm of 10-8 is -8, so the negative logarithm of 10-8is 8. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 8.

answers.text: X will likely not dissolve in the water. Y will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where Y is the solvent and water is the solute.
X will likely not dissolve in the water. Y will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where Y is the solute and water is the solvent.
X will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where X is the solute and water is the solvent. Y will likely not dissolve in the water.
X will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where X is the solvent and water is the solute. Y will likely not dissolve in the water.

questions.correct_answer: X will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where X is the solute and water is the solvent. Y will likely not dissolve in the water.
questions.neutral_comments: “X” will likely dissolve in the water because hydrophilic (“water loving”) substances tend to dissolve in water whereas “Y” will likely not dissolve in water because hydrophobic (“water fearing) substances tend not to dissolve in water. A liquid solvent, such as water, dissolves solutes, such as “X”, to form solutions.

questions.question: Which of the following would you expect to dissolve poorly in water?

answers.text: A substance with a lot of polar covalent bonds
A substance with a lot of nonpolar covalent bonds

questions.correct_answer: A substance with a lot of nonpolar covalent bonds
questions.neutral_comments: Water molecules are polar molecules as they carry partial positive and negative charges on different parts of the molecule. As a result, water molecules will tend to interact with other molecules that carry partial or full charges, including molecules with polar bonds, negatively charged molecules and atoms and positively charged molecules and anions.

questions.question: Discovery science

answers.text: focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes

questions.correct_answer: focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes
questions.neutral_comments: Discovery science describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observations and data analysis. Discovery science does NOT involve formulating hypotheses, making predictions based on those hypotheses and then testing those predictions. That is part of the process followed when doing hypothesis-based science.

questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

answers.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty

questions.correct_answer: allows rejection of a hypothesis
questions.neutral_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results
can be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results
can NOT be proven to be correct

questions.correct_answer: can NOT be proven to be correct
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

questions.question: A hypothesis must be testable and falsifiable to be scientifically valid. Being testable and falsifiable means that

answers.text: some conceivable observation or experiment could reveal whether a given hypothesis is incorrect
only a controlled experiment can prove whether a hypothesis is correct or incorrect
the hypothesis has been proved wrong
there must be several options in the hypothesis to chose from, one of which is correct

questions.correct_answer: some conceivable observation or experiment could reveal whether a given hypothesis is incorrect

questions.question: Polar molecules are often able to dissolve in water because

answers.text: The polar molecules attract each other, allowing water molecules to adsorb to them.
The polar molecules repel each other, allowing them to interact with the water molecules.
The partially charged regions of polar molecules are able to form hydrogen bonds with water molecules.
Polar molecules are able to fill their valence shells by transferring electrons from water molecules.

questions.correct_answer: The partially charged regions of polar molecules are able to form hydrogen bonds with water molecules.

questions.question: What is the pH of an aqueous solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH-] concentration of 10-12 M?
questions.correct_answer: pH 2
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-12, the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12 = 10-2. The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-2 is -2, so the negative logarithm of 10-2 is 2. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 2.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 12 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH-]?
questions.correct_answer: 0.01 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 12 = - log [H+]. Or, -12 = log [H+]. Or, 10-12 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.

questions.question: The charge on a water molecule is best described as being:

answers.text: Somewhat less than minus one near the oxygen atom and plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.
Minus one near the oxygen atom and somewhat less than plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.
Minus one near the oxygen atom and plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.
Somewhat less than minus one near the oxygen atom and somewhat less than plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.

questions.correct_answer: Somewhat less than minus one near the oxygen atom and somewhat less than plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.

questions.question: A theory is

answers.text: a poorly supported idea that has little backing but might be correct
a concept that, once established in the scientific literature, can be modified but never rejected, even when new scientific methods produce data that don’t fit
a well-supported concept that has broad explanatory power
not correct unless it is several years old

questions.correct_answer: a well-supported concept that has broad explanatory power

questions.question: Qualitative data may be collected

answers.text: when carrying out discovery science or hypothesis-based science
only when carrying out discovery science
only when carrying out hypothesis-based science
only when carrying out numerical science

questions.correct_answer: when carrying out discovery science or hypothesis-based science
questions.neutral_comments: Both quantitative and qualitative data may be collected when doing either discovery science or hypothesis-based science. Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: The method of scientific inquiry that describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observation and the analysis of data is known as
questions.correct_answer: discovery science.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about valence shells is FALSE?

answers.text: Electrons in the valence shell (i.e. valence electrons) are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.
The valence shell is the outermost electron shell of an atom.
The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
The valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has.

questions.correct_answer: The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
questions.neutral_comments: Each atom has only one valence shell, corresponding to its outermost electron shell. Because the electrons in the valence shell are the outermost electrons and the energy level of an electron increases the further it is from the nucleus, the valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has. Also, because atoms react to complete their valence shells, the valence electrons are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about chemical reactions is FALSE?

answers.text: When hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water, the hydrogen and oxygen molecules are the “reactants” of the reaction.
When hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water, the water molecules are the “products” of the reaction.
Chemical reactions may only proceed in one direction.
Chemical reactions involve the making and breaking of chemical bonds.

questions.correct_answer: Chemical reactions may only proceed in one direction.

questions.question: When two atoms share a pair of electrons, they
questions.correct_answer: form a covalent bond

questions.question: When an electron is moved further from the nucleus

answers.text: its potential energy may change, depending on how the electron was moved

questions.correct_answer: it gains potential energy
questions.neutral_comments: The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy. Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.

questions.question: Electrons exist only at fixed levels of potential energy. However, if an atom absorbs sufficient energy, a possible result is that

answers.text: an electron may move to an electron shell closer to the nucleus.
the atom would become a negatively charged ion, or anion.
the atom may become a radioactive isotope.
an electron may move to an electron shell farther away from the nucleus.

questions.correct_answer: an electron may move to an electron shell farther away from the nucleus.

questions.question: How many water molecules are needed to completely hydrolyze a polymer that is 18 nucleotides long?
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long? You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right? So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long? The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers. So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.

questions.question: If two molecules have the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures, the two molecules may be

answers.text: All of these answers are correct

In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long (note that this would be an unusually short polymer), and you could use four different types of monomers, “A”, “B”, “C” and “D”, how many different polymers could you build?
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012

answers.text: all of these answers are correct

To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships. If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose. This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers. The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as
questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.neutral_comments: Phospholipids and sterols are common in membranes. In contrast, triacylglycerol molecules are typically found in fat and are rare in membranes.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long (note that this would be an unusually short polymer), and you could use four different types of monomers, “A”, “B”, “C” and “D”, how many different polymers could you build?
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012

questions.question: If starch and cellulose are both polymers of glucose, how come people can digest starch but not cellulose?

answers.text: When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into non-sugar molecules that are impossible for us to digest.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into xylose molecules that are impossible for us to digest.

The glucose monomers that form starch are joined together by different covalent bonds than the glucose monomers that form cellulose and the enzymes in our bodies that are able to hydrolyze (break) the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in starch are not able to hydrolyze the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in cellulose.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into lactose molecules, which are hard for many people to digest.

questions.correct_answer: The glucose monomers that form starch are joined together by different covalent bonds than the glucose monomers that form cellulose and the enzymes in our bodies that are able to hydrolyze (break) the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in starch are not able to hydrolyze the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in cellulose.

questions.question: Which of the molecules listed below can form isomers? CH4 C3H8 C4H10

answers.text: CH4 and C3H8 cannot form isomers, but C4H10can form isomers
None of them can form isomers.
CH4 cannot form isomers, but C3H8 and C4H10can form isomers
All of them can form isomers

questions.correct_answer: CH4 and C3H8 cannot form isomers, but C4H10can form isomers
questions.neutral_comments: CH4 and C3H8 cannot form isomers. To see this, try drawing C3H8 molecules with different structures, remembering that each molecule you draw must have 3 carbon atoms and 8 hydrogen atoms and that each carbon atom must form 4 covalent bonds and each hydrogen atom must form 1 covalent bond. You will find that you can only draw one structure. In contrast, C4H10 can form isomers. For example, the two molecules shown below are structural isomers of C4H10.

questions.question: Molecules consisting only of carbon and hydrogen are known as
questions.correct_answer: hydrocarbons

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as
questions.correct_answer: Enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C3N2O2H3), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers. Instead, they are “enantiomers”. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other. This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other. For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups. There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up. Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon. For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups. In the molecule on the left above, the asymmetric carbon is the carbon furthest to the left. In the molecule on the right above, the asymmetric carbon is the carbon furthest to the right.

questions.question: What would be the sequence of the RNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template? 5’ AATTCGC 3’
questions.correct_answer: 5’ GCGAAUU 3’
questions.neutral_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation. In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ AATTCGC 3’RNA 3’ UUAAGCG 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ GCGAAUU 3’

questions.question: If two molecules have the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures, the two molecules may be

answers.text: All of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct
questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

They are not the same thing because one end of a polymer has a hydrogen attached and the other end of the polymer has a hydroxyl group. In other words, you could write the above molecules as: H-O-A-B-H and H-O-B-A-H, which makes it clear that they are not the same molecule.

questions.question: A dehydration reaction joins two glucose molecules to form maltose. The formula for glucose is C6H12O6. What is the correct formula for maltose?
questions.neutral_comments: You are joining two molecules of glucose to form maltose, so maltose will have twice as many atoms of each element as glucose, except that you have to remember that a water molecule is lost during the dehydration reaction. So, maltose will have 12 carbon atoms, but only 22 hydrogen atoms instead of 24 because of the two hydrogen atoms lost during formation of the water molecule. Similarly, maltose will have 11 oxygen atoms instead of 12, as one oxygen atom is used to form the water molecule.

questions.question: Identify the asymmetric carbon in this molecule

answers.text: It is the 1st carbon on the left
It is the 2nd carbon from the left
It is the 4th carbon from the left
It is the 3rd carbon from the left

questions.correct_answer: It is the 2nd carbon from the left
questions.neutral_comments: Asymmetric carbons are carbons that are covalently bonded to 4 different groups. The 1st carbon on the left in this molecule is bonded to only 3 different groups (a hydrogen atom, an oxygen atom and a hydrocarbon chain). The 3rd carbon is also bonded to only 3 different groups (two hydrogen atoms, a short hydrocarbon chain and the part of the molecule that is to the left of that carbon atom). The 4th carbon from the left is only bound to 3 different groups (2 hydrogen atoms, a methyl group and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 4th carbon). The 5th (last) carbon from the left is only bonded to 2 different groups as it forms covalent bonds with 3 hydrogen atoms and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 5th carbon. In contrast, the 2nd carbon from the left is bound to 4 different groups: a COH group, a hydrogen atom, an OH group and a short hydrocarbon chain. Each of the four different groups to which the second carbon from the left is bound is shown circled in red in the figure below.

questions.question: Which of the following terms most accurately describes the shape of an ethylene molecule?
questions.correct_answer: flat
questions.neutral_comments: The double bond between the two carbon atoms means that all the covalent bonds formed by the carbon atoms lie in a single plane. Therefore this molecule is flat. Remember that the covalent bonds formed by carbon atoms point towards the 4 corners of a tetrahedron only when the carbon atom makes bonds to 4 other atoms. In this molecule, the carbon atoms are making covalent bonds to just 3 other atoms, because the two carbon atoms are forming a double covalent bond with each other.

Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ GAGGCTT 3’DNA 3’ CTCCGAA 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ AAGCCTC 3’

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as
questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as
questions.correct_answer: Structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. However, despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond, they are NOT geometric isomers. Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms. For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group. For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms. So, the two molecules do not have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.text: Amino acids are the monomers from which proteins are formed.
Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
Sugars are the monomers from which polysaccharides are formed.
Nucleotides are the monomers from which nucleic acids are formed.

questions.correct_answer: Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
questions.neutral_comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer. In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule. For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule). In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer. In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other. For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule. So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.

questions.question: The subunit of polypeptides contains all of the following EXCEPT

answers.text: an "R" group connected to one of the carbons.

questions.correct_answer: a phosphate.

questions.question: Glucose and fructose are examples of

answers.text: all of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: Glucose and fructose have the same molecular formula (C6H12O6), but different shapes, so you can see that they are isomers of some sort. To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships. If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose. This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers. The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?
questions.correct_answer: ~ 1 billion
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 230 = ~ 1,000,000,000

questions.question: What is a triacylglycerol?

answers.text: A lipid made with three fatty acids and glycerol
A protein with a tertiary structure
A lipid that makes up much of the plasma membrane
A molecule formed from three alcohols by dehydration reactions.

questions.correct_answer: A lipid made with three fatty acids and glycerol
questions.neutral_comments: Tricacylglycerols are lipids made with three fatty acids and glycerol. They are generally used in fat storage, rather than to make membranes.

answers.text: will be determined later in the semester.

is described in the course syllabus. The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned in order to earn different final course grades.

questions.correct_answer: is described in the course syllabus. The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned in order to earn different final course grades.
questions.neutral_comments: Grades in BIOL 1009 are determined using "guaranteed point cutoffs". This means that every student in the course who earns more than a certain number of points is guaranteed to receive at least a certain letter grade. In other words, the cutoffs will NOT be raised, even if that means that every student earns a final course grade of "A". The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned (i.e. the "guaranteed point cutoffs") in order to earn different final course grades. Please note that grades are NOT curved in BIOL 1009. You can download a copy of the course syllabus from the course Canvas page.

being too sick to take the exam or being out of town for military service or certain university-approved activities (e.g., varsity sports competitions).

questions.neutral_comments: All exams must be taken, in person, during the time windows listed in the syllabus. Make-up exams will only be granted for university-approved reasons. questions.question: Scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on exams or plagiarism, is not tolerated in this course. BIOL 1009 is a required course for almost all students taking it. This means that the information covered in the course is information students will likely need to be successful in their future careers. As a result, committing scholastic dishonesty in this course is not only dis-honorable, but is also likely to negatively impact students' future careers. Because scholastic dishonesty is not tolerated in this course, students found to have committed scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on an exam:

answers.text: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
will be given an opportunity to make up some or all of the points they lost by getting a "0" on an exam or other assignment.
will be given a second chance if they promise not to do it again.

questions.correct_answer: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
questions.neutral_comments: Integrity is taken seriously in this course. The minimum penalty for students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be a grade of "0" on the assignment or exam in question, with no second chances or opportunities to make up any of the lost points. In addition, 100% of students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be reported to the UMN Office of Community Standards.

questions.question: Regarding the online quizzes:

answers.text: If you forget the deadline for a quiz, you can take it late
If you are about to submit a quiz right before the deadline and the power or internet goes out (i.e. something happens that was completely outside of your control), you can take the quiz late
If you are sick when a quiz is due, you can take it late

Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.

questions.correct_answer: Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.
questions.neutral_comments: Quizzes must be taken on time by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. Because “stuff happens”, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. So, if you do miss a quiz for any reason, that quiz will simply count as one of your three dropped quizzes and you won't have to take a zero on that quiz. To avoid missing quizzes, it is strongly recommended that you take each quiz at least once at least a day before that quiz is due. Conversely, it is strongly recommended that you NOT wait until shortly before a quiz is due to attempt it for the first time. Remember, you can take each quiz up to three times with only your highest score counting, so it makes sense to take each quiz at least once a day or two before it's due so it won't matter so much if it slips your mind the day it's due.

Conversely, it is strongly recommended that you NOT wait until shortly before a quiz is due to attempt it for the first time. questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is the same thing as a theory
is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations
is a tentative answer to a question

questions.correct_answer: is a tentative answer to a question
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

questions.question: In science, a possible answer to a specific question is know as a

answers.text: all of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: hypothesis
questions.neutral_comments: In hypothesis-based science, specific questions are asked based on prior observations or information. The tentative (possible) answers to those questions are known as “hypotheses”. Predictions are then made based on those hypotheses and the predictions are tested. Theories are broader in scope than hypotheses and so are not possible answers to specific questions, although they may be answers to really broad questions.

questions.question: What are two methods of scientific inquiry?
questions.correct_answer: discovery science and hypothesis-based science

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: can NOT be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results
can be proven to be correct
can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results

questions.correct_answer: can NOT be proven to be correct
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the logic of hypothesis-based science?

answers.text: If my prediction is correct, it will lead to a testable hypothesis.
If my hypothesis is correct, I can expect certain results.
If I generate a testable hypothesis, tests and observations will support it.
If my observations are accurate, they will support my hypothesis.

questions.correct_answer: If my hypothesis is correct, I can expect certain results.
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a possible answer to a specific question. Predictions are made based on the hypothesis and those predictions are tested (e.g. by carrying out appropriate experiments). Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, and you will often have multiple hypotheses for each question that you ask, the data you obtain will not necessarily support a particular hypothesis.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of quantitative data?

answers.text: Records of which beers taste bitter
Records of which dog breeds sometimes have black hair

questions.correct_answer: Records of plant weights
questions.correct_comments: Correct! Plant weights are measured as numerical values (e.g. how many gram or ounces each plant weighed).
questions.neutral_comments: Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

quizzes.quiz_title: SQ topic 1b level 2 (Chapter 1)

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of qualitative data?

answers.text: The six pairs of robins hatched an average of three chicks.
The fish swam in a zigzag motion.

questions.correct_answer: The fish swam in a zigzag motion.
questions.neutral_comments: Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. All of the possible answers involve numerical data, except for the data describing the fish as swimming in a zigzag motion.

questions.question: What types of data may be collected when doing hypothesis-based science?

answers.text: Only data that is partially qualitative and partially quantitative

questions.correct_answer: Quantitative and qualitative data
questions.neutral_comments: Both quantitative and qualitative data may be collected when doing either discovery science or hypothesis-based science. Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: The process whereby science experts determine whether a manuscript is suitable for publication in a scientific journal is known as
questions.correct_answer: peer review
questions.neutral_comments: During peer review, typically two to three experts in the field read the manuscript and determine whether it is suitable for publication. These experts base their opinion on whether the experiments were done in a rigorous manner, the data carefully analyzed and the interpretations of the data described in the manuscript justified by the data.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results
can NOT be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct

questions.correct_answer: can NOT be proven to be correct
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

answers.text: Records of which beers taste bitter

questions.correct_answer: Records of plant weights
questions.correct_comments: Correct! Plant weights are measured as numerical values (e.g. how many gram or ounces each plant weighed).
questions.neutral_comments: Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: Discovery science

answers.text: focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes

questions.correct_answer: focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes
questions.neutral_comments: Discovery science describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observations and data analysis. Discovery science does NOT involve formulating hypotheses, making predictions based on those hypotheses and then testing those predictions. That is part of the process followed when doing hypothesis-based science.

questions.question: The method of scientific inquiry that describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observation and the analysis of data is known as
questions.correct_answer: discovery science.

questions.question: Qualitative data may be collected

answers.text: when carrying out discovery science or hypothesis-based science
only when carrying out numerical science
only when carrying out hypothesis-based science
only when carrying out discovery science

questions.correct_answer: when carrying out discovery science or hypothesis-based science
questions.neutral_comments: Both quantitative and qualitative data may be collected when doing either discovery science or hypothesis-based science. Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is the same thing as a theory
is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations
is a tentative answer to a question

questions.correct_answer: is a tentative answer to a question
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

questions.question: What are two methods of scientific inquiry?
questions.correct_answer: discovery science and hypothesis-based science

questions.question: Which of the following statements best distinguishes hypotheses from theories in science?

answers.text: Hypotheses usually are relatively narrow in scope; theories have broad explanatory power.
Hypotheses are guesses; theories are correct answers.
Theories are proved true in all cases; hypotheses are usually falsified by tests.
Theories are hypotheses that have been proven.

questions.correct_answer: Hypotheses usually are relatively narrow in scope; theories have broad explanatory power.
questions.neutral_comments: Neither theories nor hypotheses can be proven correct beyond a shadow of a doubt. Although theories are supported by a large body of evidence, they sometimes need to be modified as new data become available. Theories are broader in scope than hypotheses.

answers.text: all of these answers are correct

questions.neutral_comments: In hypothesis-based science, specific questions are asked based on prior observations or information. The tentative (possible) answers to those questions are known as “hypotheses”. Predictions are then made based on those hypotheses and the predictions are tested. Theories are broader in scope than hypotheses and so are not possible answers to specific questions, although they may be answers to really broad questions.

questions.question: In science, a “theory”

answers.text: is supported by a large body of evidence
all of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: all of these answers are correct
questions.neutral_comments: The word “theory” does not the mean the same thing when talking about science as it does when talking about everyday life. In everyday life, “theory” is often used to mean an untested speculation. In science, a “theory” is an explanation that is broad in scope, generates new hypotheses and is supported by a large body of evidence.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best distinguishes hypotheses from theories in science?

answers.text: Hypotheses usually are relatively narrow in scope; theories have broad explanatory power.
Theories are proved true in all cases; hypotheses are usually falsified by tests.
Theories are hypotheses that have been proven.
Hypotheses are guesses; theories are correct answers.

questions.correct_answer: Hypotheses usually are relatively narrow in scope; theories have broad explanatory power.
questions.neutral_comments: Neither theories nor hypotheses can be proven correct beyond a shadow of a doubt. Although theories are supported by a large body of evidence, they sometimes need to be modified as new data become available. Theories are broader in scope than hypotheses.

questions.question: Discovery science

answers.text: focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes

questions.correct_answer: focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes
questions.neutral_comments: Discovery science describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observations and data analysis. Discovery science does NOT involve formulating hypotheses, making predictions based on those hypotheses and then testing those predictions. That is part of the process followed when doing hypothesis-based science.

questions.question: During peer-review of a manuscript

answers.text: the conclusions drawn in the manuscript are carefully considered to determine whether they are adequately supported by the data
all of these answers are correct

the experiments described in the manuscript are evaluated to determine whether they were rigorously performed

questions.correct_answer: all of these answers are correct
questions.neutral_comments: During peer review, typically two to three experts in the field read the manuscript and determine whether it is suitable for publication. These experts base their opinions on whether the experiments were done in a rigorous manner, the data carefully analyzed and the interpretations of the data described in the manuscript justified by the data.

questions.question: An explanation that is broad in scope and is supported by a large body of evidence is known in science as a

answers.text: all of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: theory
questions.neutral_comments: Theories are broad in scope; hypotheses are generally narrow in scope. Theories are typically supported by a larger body of evidence than any one hypothesis. Predictions are made based on hypotheses. For example, if your hypothesis is that your phone doesn’t work because the battery is dead, you might make the prediction that re-charging your phone will fix it.

questions.question: Through careful experimentation or observations, it is possible to prove

answers.text: neither a hypothesis nor a theory
a theory, but not a hypothesis
a hypothesis, but not a theory
either a hypothesis or a theory

questions.correct_answer: neither a hypothesis nor a theory
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a theory or hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular theory or hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted them correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about hypotheses is FALSE?

answers.text: Hypotheses should be possible answers to specific questions.

questions.correct_answer: Hypotheses should be provable.
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false.

questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

answers.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty

questions.correct_answer: allows rejection of a hypothesis
questions.neutral_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about moles is true?

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct.
questions.neutral_comments: All of these answers are correct. A mole is 6.02 X 1023. A hydrogen atom weighs one Dalton so one mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g. One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g. This is because hydrogen molecules have the formula: H2. questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH-] concentration of 10-4.5 M?
questions.correct_answer: pH 9.5
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 M (moles per liter) in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-4.5 M, the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-4.5= 10-9.5 M. The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-9.5 is -9.5, so the negative logarithm of 10-9.5is 9.5. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 9.5.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 12 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH-]?
questions.correct_answer: 0.01 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 12 = - log [H+]. Or, -12 = log [H+]. Or, 10-12 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.

questions.neutral_comments: Nitrogen atoms have 5 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so nitrogen needs to form 3 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 3 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and one pair of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.

The valence shell is the outermost electron shell of an atom.

questions.correct_answer: The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
questions.neutral_comments: Each atom has only one valence shell, corresponding to its outermost electron shell. Because the electrons in the valence shell are the outermost electrons and the energy level of an electron increases the further it is from the nucleus, the valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has. Also, because atoms react to complete their valence shells, the valence electrons are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.

questions.question: What gives rise to the cohesiveness of water molecules?
questions.correct_answer: Hydrogen bonds
questions.neutral_comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge. As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.

questions.question: When a sodium atom and a chlorine atom interact to complete their valence shells

answers.text: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into an anion and the chlorine atom into a cation and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond

questions.correct_answer: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
questions.neutral_comments: Chlorine is so much more electronegative than sodium that, rather than sharing a pair of electrons, the lone electron in the valence (= 3rd) shell of sodium is transferred to chlorine. That leaves the sodium cation with no electrons in the 3rd electron shell and a full set (8) of electrons in the 2nd electron shell. The 1 electron transferred to the chlorine atom is sufficient to complete the valence shell of that atom. Because chlorine now has one more electron than it has protons, the chlorine anion will have a charge of negative 1. Negatively charged ions are called “anions” and positively charged ions are called “cations”.

Carbon is only slightly more electronegative than hydrogen and so will not remove electrons from hydrogen. In addition, removing 4 electrons from hydrogen atoms to complete its valence shell would leave carbon with 4 more electrons than protons, which is energetically extremely unfavorable.

questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH-] concentration of 10-4 M?

The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-10 is -10, so the negative logarithm of 10-10is 10. questions.question: The number of electron orbitals in the different electron shells is

answers.text: 2 in the 1st shell and 4 in the second shell

2 in the 1st shell and 8 in the second shell
1 in the 1st shell and 4 in the second shell

questions.correct_answer: 1 in the 1st shell and 4 in the second shell
questions.neutral_comments: The first electron shell has one orbital and the second electron shell has four orbitals. Each orbital can contain a maximum of two electrons. Therefore the first electron shell can contain up to two electrons and the second electron shell can contain up to eight electrons.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do carbon atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so carbon needs to form 4 covalent bonds so that it is sharing a total of 8 electrons (2 electrons per covalent bond).

questions.question: The lowest energy mechanism by which a carbon atom may complete its valence shell is to

answers.text: transfer the 4 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 4 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
transfer the 2 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 2 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms
form 4 covalent bonds with other atoms

questions.correct_answer: form 4 covalent bonds with other atoms
questions.neutral_comments: Forming only 2 covalent bonds with other atoms would not be sufficient for a carbon atom to complete its shell, as carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell (= the 2nd electron shell) and 8 electrons are needed to complete that shell. In theory the outermost shell could be completed by transferring 4 electrons from other atoms, but in practice this would leave the carbon atom with 4 more electrons than protons which is very unfavorable energetically. In theory the outermost shell could also be completed by transferring 4 electrons FROM carbon to other atoms, in which case the carbon atom would have no electrons in its 2nd shell and 2 electrons in its 1st shell, which would make the 1st shell its outermost, or valence, shell and that shell would be complete since it only takes 2 electrons to fill the 1st electron shell. However, this situation would leave the carbon atom with 4 less electrons than protons, which is a big difference in the number of electrons and protons and is extremely unstable in this case.

questions.question: Depending on how far an electron is moved from the nucleus

answers.text: you can decrease its potential energy by any amount
you can decrease its potential energy by only certain amounts
you can increase its potential energy by any amount
you can increase its potential energy by only certain amounts

questions.correct_answer: you can increase its potential energy by only certain amounts
questions.neutral_comments: The potential energy of electrons increases the further they are from the nucleus. However, electrons may only occupy certain defined orbitals that have certain defined average distances from the nucleus and thus certain energy levels. Think of it like a ball being moved up or down a set of steps. If a ball is moved up two steps its energy level will increase twice as much as if it is moved up one step (assuming the steps are of equal height). However, it is not feasible to increase the potential energy of the ball by 0.5 or 1.5 steps.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about electrons is FALSE?

answers.text: two electrons may occupy the same electron orbital

questions.correct_answer: the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus and therefore the more potential energy the electron has
questions.neutral_comments: It is true that the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus. However, it is NOT true that an electron has more potential energy when it is closer to the nucleus. In fact, it will have less potential energy the closer it gets to the nucleus. Think of it this way, the further from the earth you send a rocket, the less strongly it is attracted to the earth by gravity, but the more potential energy it has.

answers.text: it depends on the water molecule
